repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired by gift and purchase, 1941-1996. For more information consult the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 22: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Benét Family Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Benét Family Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Benét Family Collection contains material acquired by the library through gift and purchase from 1941 through 1979. Manuscript material formerly classified under multiple call numbers, as well as printed ephemera that had been cataloged separately, was brought together and processed during 2016-2017.
Former call numbers: Za Benét, Uncat Za Ms 143, Uncat Za Ms 294, Uncat Za File 13, Uncat Za File 37, Uncat Za File 225, Uncat Za File 383, Uncat Za File 415, and Za B436 +1.

bioghist.head: Benét family
bioghist.p: Brigadier General S. V. (Stephen Vincent) Benét was born 22 January 1827 in St. Augustine, Florida. He studied at Hallowell's school in Alexandria, Virginia and then at the University of Georgia and the United States Military Academy, where he graduated in 1849. He was appointed to the Ordnance Corps, and served at the Watervliet Arsenal, at Washington, at Frankford Arsenal, again at Washington, and then at the St. Louis Arsenal. In 1859 he became Assistant Professor of Geography, History, and Ethics at West Point, and from 1861 until 1864 was instructor of Ordnance and the Science of Gunnery. From 1865 until 1869 he was in command of Frankford arsenal. In 1869 he became Assistant to the Chief of Ordnance, and in 1874 he succeeded to Chief of Ordnance with the rank of Brigadier General. He translated Jomini's " Political and Military History of the Campaign of Waterloo" (New York, 1853) and he is the author of a treatise on "Military Law and the Practice of Courts-Martial" (1862) and "Electro-Ballistic Machines and the Schultze Chronoscope" (1866).
He married Laura Amanda Walker and together they had two sons, James Walker Benét and Laurence Vincent Benét.

James Walker Benét (1857-1928), a Colonel in the U.S. Army, was born 16 July, 1857 in Richmond, Kentucky. He graduated from West Point Academy in 1880 and went on to serve most of his military career in the Army Ordnance Department. From 1890 until his retirement in 1921, he served at the Frankford Arsenal, Philadelphia (1890-1984); Bethlehem Iron Works, South Bethlehem, Pennsylvania (1894-1898); Ordnance Headquarters, Buffalo, New York (1898-1899); Watervliet Arsenal, New York (1904-1905, 1919-1921); Rock Island Arsenal, Illinois (1904-1905), Benicia Arsenal, California (1905-1911), and Augusta Arsenal, Georgia (1911-1918).

James Walker Benét married Frances Neill Rose (1860-1940) of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1883. Ms. Rose, born 23 October, 1860 in Washington, D.C., was the child of William John Rose and Mary Lee Mahon. She attended Mrs. Sutton's School for Girls. Their children include authors Laura Benét, William Rose Benét, and Stephen Vincent Benét.

Laura Benét (1884-1979) was educated at the Emma Willard School in Troy, New York, and at Vassar and Moravian colleges. She worked at the Spring Street Settlement in New York City from 1915 to 1917 and at the American Red Cross in Augusta, Georgia from 1917 to 1919. She later took on editorial and free-lance writing assignments. She was the author of several poetry collections, fiction, and biographical works.

William Rose Benét (1886-1950) was educated at Albany Academy and Yale College (1903-1907). After college, Benét worked for Century Magazine as a reader. He served in the U.S. Air Services during the First World War, and after the war took work as a copy writer for an advertising firm. In 1920, Henry Seidel Canby brought Benét on as an assistant editor at the New York Evening Post and in 1923, Canby, Benét, and their fellow editors left the Post to form the Saturday Review .

William Rose Benét was the author of several collections of poetry, a novel, and a collection of essays. His autobiography in verse, The Dust Which Is God (1941), was awarded a Pulitzer Prize in 1942. In addition to his long-standing (1923-1950) position with the Saturday Review , Benét contributed to several compilations of English-language poetry and literature.

William Rose Benét married four times, to: Teresa Frances Thomson (1912-1919), with whom he had three children, James Walker Benét (1914-2012), Kathleen Anne (Benét) Fry, and Frances Rosemary (Benét) Dawson; poet Elinor Wylie (1923-1928); actress Lora Baxter (1932-1937); and children's book author Majorie Flack (1941-1950).

Stephen Vincent Benét (1898-1943), educated at Summerville Academy and Yale College (1915-1919), was a well known and widely read author in the United States during the 1930s and 1940s. After the success of his long poem, John Brown's Body (1928), for which he was awarded a Pulitzer Prize in 1929, he regularly published poems, short stories, and other work in popular magazines such as The Atlantic Monthly , The New Yorker , and The Saturday Evening Post . His short story, "The Devil and Daniel Webster" (1936) was awarded the O. Henry Memorial Award in 1937. In addition to poetry and short stories, he is the author of novels, book reviews, essays, radio and stage plays, screenplays, and speeches.
Stephen Vincent Benét and Rosemary Carr married in 1921. They had three children, Thomas, Stephanie Jane, and Rachel.
Biographical information taken from Arlington National Cemetary website and other sources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Benét family collection consists of correspondence, writings, and other material documenting personal and professional activities of members of the literary Benét family. The collection features material by and relating to William Rose Benét and Stephen Vincent Benét.

Noteworthy correspondence files for Stephen Vincent Benét can be found with Yale College classmates Shreve Cowles Badger and John Chipman Farrar, with the literary agency Brandt & Brandt, for which there are approximately 227 pieces of correspondence, and with publishers Doubleday, Doran & Company and Farrar & Rinehart.

Larger correspondence files for William Rose Benét can be found with his third wife, Lora Baxter, the poets Jeremy Ingalls and Starr Nelson, and the Saturday Review . There are approximately 92 pieces of correspondence from Benét to Baxter, and the Starr Nelson gift consists of six scrapbooks containing approximately 360 letters between Nelson and Benét, as well as photographs, drafts or fair copies of writings, clippings, and printed ephemera.

The two largest groups of manuscript writings for Stephen Vincent Benét can be found in the Farrar & Rinehart Gift, which includes approximately 200 reader reports, and in the Material from Other Sources series, which includes drafts and printed versions of several works. For example, there are drafts of the poetry collection, Songs of Dear Old Yale , and a musical score, "The Headless Horseman," done in collaboration with Douglas Moore.

Drafts of poems and other writings by William Rose Benét can be found in the Reese Baxter and Wallace G. Fiske gifts. Other writings in the collection include a draft, typescript and autograph manuscript, of an autobiography by Colonel James Walker Benét.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: I. Shreve Cowles Badger Gifts, 1918-1944. II. Reese Baxter Gift, 1932-1958. III. Brandt & Brandt Gift, 1930-1943. IV. John Chipman Farrar Gifts, 1918-1960. V. Farrar & Rinehart Gift, 1933-1957. VI. Wallace G. Fiske Gift, 1914-1959. VII. Henry R. Hallowell Gifts, 1920-1958. VIII. Starr Nelson Gift, 1942-1950. IX. Material from Other Sources, 1912-1979.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Material by or relating to the Benét family acquired by the library from family sources is located in the Benét Family Papers (YCAL MSS 1107). Additional material by or relating to Stephen Vincent and Rosemary Benét can be found in the Stephen Vincent Benét and Rosemary Benét Papers (YCAL MSS 1046). Additional material by or relating to William Rose Benét can be found in the William Rose Benét Papers (YCAL MSS 1100).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Shreve Cowles Badger gift contains correspondence to Badger from members of the Benét family and others and writings by and about Stephen Vincent Benét. Correspondence features 30 pieces of correspondence to Badger from Stephen Vincent Benét, a Yale College classmate.

processinfo.p: Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 143.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Reese Baxter gift contains correspondece, writings, and other material relating chiefly to William Rose Benét and Lora Baxter. Benét and Baxter were married from 1932 until 1937, and the group features approximately 92 pieces of correspondence from Benét to Baxter dating from 1932 until the year of his death, 1950. There are drafts and printed versions of poems by Benét and, among other materials, there is a copy of Benét's last will and testament.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brandt & Brandt gift consists of the literary agency's correspondence file for Stephen Vincent Benét for the period from 1930 through 1943. There are approximately 227 pieces of correspondence from Benét to various representatives of the firm, including many to founder Carl Brandt. Letters concern literary and personal topics, with many relating to stories and articles for publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, and printed material relating to Stephen Vincent Benét assembled by Yale college classmate, and publisher, John Chipman Farrar.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Farrar & Rinehart gift comprises the publisher's files for Stephen Vincent Benét. There are general correspondence files for Rosemary and Stephen Vincent Benét containing original letters, carbons of letters from Farrar & Rinehart, and third party correspondence with other publishers and the literary agency Brandt & Brandt. There are also files relating to a memorial, permissions, publicity, and individual works by Benét.

Other material features approximately 200 reader reports written by Benét on different titles. This group of material would appear to represent what amounts to Benét's unpublished literary criticism. Reports, typewritten, vary in length from a few lines to several pages. Most reports are written in an epistolary style, addressed to John Farrar or others in the firm. In reports, Benét highlights or criticizes aspects of the work, offers his opinion on whether or not Farrar & Rinehart should publish the work, and sometimes either identifies areas needing attention or offers advice to authors on how to move forward.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Writings, and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fiske gift contains material relating to the Benét family, and William Rose Benét in particular, assembled by the Reverend Emerson Hugh Lalone. Correspondence includes subdivisions for letters to Lalone and to William Rose Benét. There are several pieces of writing by Benét, including corrected typescript drafts of a possible story, "Gowden Elspie," and article, "Night Thoughts of a Goldsmith." Miscellaneous other material, such as biographical information, clippings, and photographs, relate chiefly to William Rose Benét.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letter to Coe William Rose Benét and material relating to The Dust Which Is God

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Starr Nelson gift features six scrapbooks ("volumes") containing correspondence between Nelson and William Rose Benét. Correspondence, including approximately 360 original letters between Nelson and Benét, is arranged in chonological order from 1942 until 1950. Volumes also contain photographs, drafts or fair copies of writings, clippings, and printed ephemera.

The correspondence between the two appears to start with a short autograph letter from Benét (1886-1950) to Nelson (1910-?), dated August 12, 1942, in which Benét informs Nelson that he is accepting her poem, "The Lovers in Ascension," for publication in the Saturday Review .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes copies of poems and photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Writings, and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material from Other Sources contains other small gifts and purchases of material relating to the Benét family. Correspondence is subdivided for Stephen Vincent and William Rose Benét correspondence and consists chiefly of outgoing letters. The largest files can be found for correspondence between Stephen Vincent Benét and the publisher Doubleday and Company, and for correspondence between William Rose Benét and the poet Jeremy Ingalls and the Saturday Review . The Saturday Review file contains original letters to Benét and other staff members at the journal, original letters from Benét to other staff, and carbons of outgoing letters. A good amount of Saturday Review correspondence is with translator Rae Dalven.

Writings feature multiple works, inclduing drafts and printed versions, by Stephen Vincent Benét. Other noteworky writings include a draft, typescript and autogarph manuscript, of an autobiography by James Walker Benét (1857-1928) and a setting copy, corrected and with printer's annotations, of Muriel Rukeyser's Theory of Flight (Yale University Press, 1935). Rukeyser's collection was awarded the Yale Younger Poets Prize in 1934. Stephen Vincent Benét, who served as editor of the series from 1933 to 1942, made the selection and wrote a foreward to the 1935 publication.
